II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation

provided food if they returned to the facility.
Additional Findings Yes

service plan was completed and determined it lacked the required

III. METHODOLOGY
05/25/2022 Special Investigation Intake2022C0214023.
05/25/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
05/25/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with Complainant 1 and
Complainant 2.
05/25/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with Complainant 3.
05/25/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with DHHS Worker.
05/25/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with DHHS Supervisor.
05/25/2022 Contact - Document Received: Youth A’s Updated Service Plan.
05/26/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with Youth A.
05/26/2022 Inspection Completed On-site
05/26/2022 Contact - Face to Face: interviews with Administrator 1, Staff 1,
Staff 2, Youth B, and Youth C.
05/26/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with Administrator 2.
05/27/2022 Contact - Telephone call made: Interview with Staff 3.
06/06/2022 Contact - Document Received: Residential Updated Service Plan.
06/07/2022 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
06/07/2022 Pre exit meeting with Administrator 1 and Administrator 2.
ALLEGATION:
The manager attempted to pay someone outside of the facility to assault this youth.
The manager destroyed a youth's room for having a ketchup packet in the room.
There may be photo evidence.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant 1, Complainant 2 and Complainant 3 reside together.
2

Complainant 1 was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. Prior to working at the
facility, she observed Youth A sitting outside of the facility. Complainant 3 was
standing next to Youth A. Complainant 3 informed Complainant 1 that Administrator
1 would pay Complainant 3, twenty dollars if he could get Youth A back into the
facility. Complainant 1 also reported being told by Youth A that Administrator 1 said
he was not going to feed Youth A and had taken his DVD player away from him.
Complainant 1 walked with Youth A to the facility door where Administrator 1 told
Youth A he could earn his belongings back if he behaves. Later in the day,
Administrator 1 came to the complainant’s home and paid Complainant 3 ten dollars
for helping with Youth A. Complainant 1 reported Complainant 3 informed her
Administrator 1 wanted him to hurt Youth A and was going to pay him twenty dollars
not ten dollars. Complainant 1 later began to work for the facility for one day. When
she went to her orientation at the facility, Administrator 1 showed staff a picture of a
"big mess" in Youth B's room and told the staff “He (Administrator 1) destroyed the
room and made Youth B clean it up". Youth B was also seen in the picture, and he
looked scared while "sitting on the floor holding his knees". She believes this
occurred because Youth B put ketchup on the walls of his room. Administrator 1 told
her Youth C is faking his disability and his mother was a "train wreak". Complainant
1 reported the youth go straight to their rooms after school and only come out when
it is time to eat. Staff 1 and Staff 3 were also witness to these events at the facility.
Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. He reported being
related to Complainant 1 and being told by Administrator 1 he had to "jack up" Youth
A so he took him off camera to do so. He also reported developing a relationship
with Administrator 1 when they met at the bus stop.
Complainant 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. He reported being
offered money ($20) to take Youth A back to the facility. When he reached the
facility, Administrator 1 told him to hit Youth A, but he didn't and only tried to get
Youth A into the facility. Administrator used the term "pop his ass upside the head",
when asking him to hit Youth A. He also reported being told by Youth A,
Administrator 1 hit him and took his DVD player.
DHHS Worker was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. DHHS Worker reported
Youth A would run away but he always returned. She reported never having any
concerns about his placement at the facility and Youth A always reported things
were good.
DHHS Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. She reported Youth
A never reported any negative experience while at the facility. The agency is
pleased with the service provided.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 5/26/22. He reported missing
Administrator 1 and really liked Administrator 1. He liked everything about the facility
and felt safe while there. He never felt uncomfortable but was scared once but can't
3

remember why he was scared. He was unable to identify anything negative about
his stay at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/26/22. He is limited in
his verbal interactions but did not report any issues or fears. He presented as clean
and well cared for.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/26/22. He is unable to
communicate verbally. He presented as well cared for and happy.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility and Administrator 2
was on the phone on 5/26/22. Administrator 1 denied telling anyone to beat up a
youth in the program or hitting any youth. He denied using the type of language that
was described by Complainant 3 when reporting what Administrator 1 told him about
beating up Youth A. Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 reported taking the
computer away from Youth B because he was looking at "porn" but also providing a
tablet that had restrictions on it for his games. Youth A would not have his DVD
player to use when he “ran away” but upon his return he was provided the DVD
player again. They denied removing items as punishment to any youth.
Administrator 1 denied saying anything negative about Youth C's mother and
reported they have a very good relationship. He also denied saying Youth C is faking
his developmental delays and believes Youth C is more aware of his environment
that he may let on at times.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility,on 5/26/22. She denied ever
witnessing a photo of Youth B's room in a messy condition. She also reported never
hearing Administrator 1 speak in negative terms to the youth and she believes the
facility is a good place to work. She feels very supported by the administration.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/26/22. He reported
working at the facility since 5/20/22. He completed orientation and never witnessed
any pictures of rooms that were messy. He also has no knowledge of ketchup on the
walls of Youth B's room. He has experienced nothing negative and all the
interactions between Administrator 1 and youth have been very positive. He has met
the families of youth at the facility and the families are very happy with the progress
the youth have made.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/27/22. He reported beginning his
employment at the facility on 4/6/22 and has never seen pictures outlined in the
allegations. He was unaware of Youth A running away and knows nothing of the
allegations of Administrator 1 wanting to pay someone to beat Youth A. All the
interactions he has witnessed between Administrator 1 and the youth have been
very positive.
Documents Reviewed:
4

Case Service Plan for Youth A dated 5/12/22 with a report period of 2/12/22 to
5/12/22 and written by DHHS Worker. This document outlines Youth A’s
placement at the facility from 4/6/22- 5/1/22.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Staff Qualifications
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance. Complainant 3 reported
Administrator 1 offered him money to hit Youth A, however
Administrator 1 denied this claim. There are no other witnesses
to this interaction. Further, Complainant 1 reported
Administrator 1 showed a picture of Youth B’s bedroom after
Administrator 1 had destroyed it and he said inappropriate
things regarding Youth C, indicating Staff 1 and Staff 3 were
present. Administrator 1, Staff 1 and Staff 3 denied this
occurred.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth receive little food. A youth that was previously placed at the facility was
outside and told by the manager that they would not be supplied food if they
returned to the facility. Manager at the facility has a menu posted that is not
followed.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant 1 was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. She reported working
at the facility for one day. She did not observe food in the freezer. She reported the
facility will only feed the youth one item for a meal. She reported Administrator 1
laughed when she asked about a snack and Administrator 1 informed her, they were
working on helping Youth A lose weight. Complainant 1 also reported Administrator
1 told the staff he doesn't follow the menu and only has it because of the "state
rules".
DHHS Worker was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. She reported never
being told by Youth A he was not being provided appropriate meals. Youth A loved
Administrator 1's cooking and never talked about being locked outside.
DHHS Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on 5/25/22. She reported Youth
A never reported any negative experience while at the facility. The agency is
pleased with the service provided.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 5/26/22. He reported he liked
everything about the facility and had lots of food to eat. He was never hungry.
5

Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility and Administrator 2
was on the phone on 5/26/22. Both denied "ever" withholding food from youth and
they follow the menu as much as the youth will allow. Both reported following the
menu as much as the youth will allow. Both report because of the nature of the
autism issues with the youth, at times they refuse to eat what is prepared and
adjustments must be made to provide something they will eat. Youth C struggles
with his meals because of sensory issues and often his meals are changed so he
will eat
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/26/22. She denied food is
withheld from youth and the youth are provided a full meal each time. She reported
knowing Youth C struggles with food, but staff will provide different options of food.
She reported the facility follows the menu as much as possible because of the needs
of the youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/26/22. He reported youth
are provided all meals (several items) and the menu is followed except for Youth C,
who at times refuses to eat. They will provide other options for him.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/27/22. He denied Youth A was ever
denied food and meals are prepared according to the menu. He also reported meals
can change because a youth may struggle eating different items, but they prepare
different foods for the youth.
Tour:
A walk through of the facility took place on 5/26/22. The kitchen was inspected
along with the food storage, refrigerator, and freezer. There was a significant amount
of dry goods in the storage, food in the refrigerator, and frozen items in the freezer.
There was also food on the counter that matched what was on the menu for dinner.
A meal menu is posted in the kitchen area.
Documentation Reviewed:
A review of the daily menu was conducted. Each meal is made up of several
items and cover the three basic daily meal. The meals appear appropriate.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
(2) Meals shall be of sufficient quantity to meet the nutritional
allowances recommended by USDA guidelines:
(www.healthierus.gov/dietaryguidelines)
(4) Menus, including snacks if provided, shall be written and
posted prior to the serving of the meal. Any change or
substitution shall be noted and considered as part of the original
menu. Menus shall be retained for 1 year.
6

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance with the youth nutrition. None
of the staff and youth interviewed shared an issue with a lack of
food. The walk-through of the facility provided evidence of
appropriate levels of food present as well a meal menu posted.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended to the facility that they develop a separate
menu for youth who struggle with food items. Any change to the
items served must also be documented.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During this investigation, a review of Youth A’s initial residential service plan was
completed and determined it lacked the required information.
INVESTIGATION:
Residential Updated Service Plan dated 4/6/22 with a report period of 4/6/22 to
5/2/22. The identified domains of needs include Mental Health and Well-Being,
Education, and Life Skills. There are no goals listed in the treatment plan section.
Under the goals section it is stated, "Behavior modification with CCI request and
behaviors & social interactions". There are no objective, expected outcomes, time
frames, person responsible for coordination, and staff techniques identified.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(c) Treatment goals to remedy the problems of the resident
and family, and time frames for achieving the goals.
(d) Indicators of goal achievement.
(e) The person responsible for coordinating and
implementing the resident and family treatment goals.
(f) Staff techniques for achieving the resident’s treatment
goals, including a specific behavior management plan. The plan
shall be designed to minimize seclusion and restraint and
include a continuum of responses to problem behaviors.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as the initial service plan
does not have the requirements for the treatment goals outlined.
Several items are missing including the goals, objective,
expected outcomes, time frames, person responsible for
coordination, and staff techniques identified.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
7

I recommend no change to the license status of this child caring institution.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation concerned serious allegations against the manager of Pine Way Group South, including soliciting an assault on a youth and destroying a youth's room, along with complaints about food provision. The primary allegations of abuse and food issues were not substantiated by witness interviews or physical evidence, though some staff statements contradicted the administrator's denials. However, a review of Youth A's service plan revealed it lacked required components. Given the unsubstantiated, yet concerning, abuse claims and the clear documentation failure, administrative oversight appears more culpable than direct abuse in this instance.
